newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices down 1/8 to 1/4.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices down 1/8 to 1/4.

text.p: U.S. Municipal bond prices ended down 1/8 to 1/4 point Monday, while on the new issue side Lehman Brothers said it may postpone a $932 million Port Authority of New York and New Jersey deal until next week.
"It's very quiet today," a municipal trader said. "It's a Monday. I don't think anyone has any idea where this market is going. We have a decent calendar, so everyone waits for the calendar."

Even without the Port Authority's deal, which may be delayed to allow institutional investors more time to review sales documents, several other big deals are slated, among them a $543 million New York City Municipal Assistance Corporation deal.
The offering, expected through JP Morgan Securities Inc on Wednesday, has a one-day retail order period set for Tuesday.
Also Wednesday, Goldman Sachs & Co is expected to price s $500 million Chicago School Reform Board of Trustees offering.
On the competitive side, Florida is expected to sell $300 million of Department of Environmental Protection revenue bonds through competitive bidding at 1100 EDT Tuesday.
A trader said while some municipal bond funds apparently have money to spend, they are waiting to see which direction the market takes.

"I think once there's some direction, you'll see the money spent whether it's on the upside or the downside," he said. "They're just unsure. We have a few accounts that are making a bet that it's going down."
The trader said he tended to agree with those accounts given the Federal Reserves' apparent "tightening mode."

Back in Monday's muni cash market, a municipal analyst said high grades ended slightly weaker overall, with longer issues worsening by about two basis points. Dollar bonds closed down 1/8 to 1/4 point, and secondary activity was light.
In debt futures, the June Municipal contract closed down 7/32 at 112-19/32. The June T-bond contract closed down 11/32 at 107-21/32. The MOB spread was 158 ticks.
In the government cash market, the benchmark 30-year bond closed down 14/32 at 94-8/32 to yield 7.09 percent.
